let us begin by going over the definition of nutrients and nutrition so
that we can all be really clear on what we're talking about the nutrients are
defined as a substance that provide nourishment which are essential for

so when we're talking about nutrition we're really talking about the optimal

our nutrients really well nutrients are molecules that all organisms need in
order to make energy grow and reproduce they are broken down into three main
nutrient groups utilized by the organism which are macronutrients micronutrients
and phytonutrients let's take a closer look macronutrients are the class of
chemical compounds which humans consume the largest quantities of and come in
the form of carbohydrates proteins and fats water and oxygen are also consumed
in large quantities but are not always considered food or nutrients
however calcium salt magnesium and potassium are sometimes added to this
list of macronutrients because they are required in larger quantities than most
other micronutrients let's look at each macronutrient individually
a carbohydrate is a biological molecule consisting of carbon hydrogen and oxygen
atoms usually with a two-to-one hydrogen to oxygen ratio the same ratio lies and
water the most common and abundant forms of carbohydrates are sugars fibers and
starches carbohydrates in their simplest forms are used by the body and mind as
an energy source by providing glucose to ourselves and cellulose as digestive
fiber there are two basic types of carbs simple and complex which vary depending
on their chemical structure and each is received by your body differently simple
carbs are basic sugars and give you a quick spike in energy if you have too
much though it can overload your liver and turn to stored fat in your body in
the standard American diet they are most often found in processed sugars which
besides quick energy holds no nutritional value simple carbs also
occurred naturally in fruits and vegetables which is the best place to
find them because fruits and vegetables naturally contain other nutrients
complex carbs on the other hand are things like fiber and starch which can
take longer to process by the body and carries far more nutrients within due to
their complex molecular chain fibers themselves are not actually even
processed they are just used by the body to push things through starches and
fibers are found in virtually all unrefined plant-based foods
the key with carbohydrates are finding the right carb not avoiding them
altogether generally the more complex carbohydrates that you eat the better
off you'll be interestingly enough there's a
long-standing myth that the human brain evolves because we began eating meat
however the neurons in the brain run almost exclusively on glucose not

protein is a major structural component of cells and is responsible for the
building and repairing of body tissues proteins are broken down into amino
acids which are organic compounds essential for every metabolic process in
the body nine of the 20 amino acids known as essential amino acids must be
provided in the diet as they apparently cannot be synthesized by the body as
we've mentioned before many people believe that they have to get all of

while they both can be valuable in their own right there are many plant sources
which have even higher amounts of protein in them - their meat
counterparts plus with the lack of heme iron or high
levels of saturated fat which come along with animal proteins we find that

vital building block for growing hair building muscle bones cartilage skin and
blood and even helps you stay satiated once you've finished eating a meal and
today many nutritionists believe that between 10 to 35 percent of your daily
calories should be protein rich the next macronutrient in the list is fat also
called lipids these are the macronutrient which stores energy for
our bodies fats have long chains of carbon and
hydrogen and when consumed increase the absorption of fat soluble vitamins such

properly to enjoy body organs against shock keep body temperature stable and
maintain healthy skin and hair as with proteins the body cannot manufacture

most unsaturated fats are really good for you like
which comes from an avocado and saturated fats can have benefits in very

you can do by looking out for anything that says partially hydrogenated in the

might hear about and a part of the fat family is called cholesterol this is a

essential role in our brain which contain about 25% of the cholesterol in
our bodies and is critical for the formation of mental synapses there's a
lot of concern in the world about high cholesterol it's being one of the

vitamins which assist in helping ourselves to make energy vitamins are

the vitamin B group supports cell metabolism and while there are a lot of

potassium is an electrolyte which conducts electricity in the body and is
critical to heart function and musculoskeletal contractions
sodium maintains the water and electrolyte balance in the body both
inside and outside of the cell and is important in how nerves and muscles
works chloride helps maintain blood volume blood pressure and the pH of your

of bones and teeth in fact about eighty-five percent of the body's

type of nutrients phytonutrients
phytonutrients are Greeks for plant and nutrients and our plant chemicals which
have been scientifically proven to provide health benefits such as
providing support for optimal cellular function and communication these
nutrients are in their own classification because they're not
related to fats carbohydrates proteins vitamins or minerals the benefits of
phytonutrients include antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties they may
also enhance immunity and intercellular communication repair DNA damage from
exposure to toxins detoxify carcinogens and alter estrogen metabolism the US
Department of Agriculture has stated that consuming a phytonutrient
rich diet seems to be an effective strategy for reducing cancer and heart
disease risk why no nutrient rich foods include
colorful fruits and vegetables legumes nuts tea whole grains many spices and
pretty much all plant-based food having looked at the different types of
nutrients we can start to look at disease and illnesses that occur within
our physical bodies as a result of our diets disease itself is defined as a
disorder of structure or function in a human animal or plant especially one
that produces the specific signs or symptoms or that affects a specific
location and is not simply a direct result of physical injury the discussion
of nutrition and disease actually go hand-in-hand and are commonly described
as nutritional deficiencies nutritional deficiencies often come in four ways
conditions that interfere with nutrient utilization conditions that cause a
greater than normal need for a nutrient conditions that cause nutrient
destruction in the body or conditions that cause greater nutrient excretion
out of the body we can see in modern science where nutrition is out of
balance disease runs rampant this can lead to a wide array of problems in the
body including but not limited to obesity wasting eating disorders
cardiovascular disease hypertension cancer and diabetes and even the more
common but less severe sounding diseases such as fatigue weakness trouble
breathing hair loss constipation heart
palpitations depression a lack of concentration and many others all of
which can be caused by an imbalance of nutrients in the body all of this
information seems to be saying that when there is a disease in the body
especially which has been caused or impacted by nutrition resolving the
problems with nutrition can resolve the disease at its core and even eliminated
completely this is not to say that just eating proper nutrition alone can solve
all of our problems outright so there are a wide array of diseases out there
but it's safe to say that a lot of them are caused or made worse by poor
nutrition and we can help heal the body by bringing awareness to this and making
changes when needed let's take vitamin C for example if
we're vitamin C decision we can find ourselves getting no sleep having rough
or dry skin wounds healing slowly easy to bruise weak immune system digestive
disorders harder to lose weight high blood pressure gallbladder disease or
even having strokes and certain cancers these are all potential results from
having a lack of vitamin C there were studies done in the 1940s like doctors
William Jay McCormick and Frederick Leonard who wrote about their success in
treating disease with high doses of vitamin C the reason that one vitamin
can cure so many diseases is because the lack of the same vitamin can cause so
many diseases there are really only about two dozen nutrients with thousands
of chemical reactions taking places in the
body and each nutrient is involved in a multitude of reactions that the body
experiences and they all need to be present and balanced for our bodies to
thrive studies have found that vitamin C acts as an antitoxin antihistamine
antiviral a blood sugar regulators and even a mood elevator the list goes on
and on now there are a lot of studies and speculations out there that vitamin

that's why the public and physicians see all these research papers that show
ambiguous results one study is published and those vitamins help a little bit
another study is published it says vitamins don't help very much and you
have this back and forth but the problem is because all of those studies are low
dose studies in fact on the news that said you shouldn't take too many of
those regular genome is not going to be that idiot
and yet they don't provide any evidence of that they just say it this doesn't
mean to say that you should just start taking massive doses of vitamins
remember we only need a small amount to maintain balance in the body and for
further clarity we are talking about two different things here vitamins and
vitamin supplements ideally you shouldn't have to take any vitamin
supplements if you're getting all of the vitamins necessary from the food that
you're eating however if you're nutritionally depleted the vitamin
supplements can give you a boost for your body to get back into a natural
state of being though you should aim not to need to
take supplements in the long run and sustain yourself entirely on the whole
natural food there is still also the challenge that most of the foods
available today are lacking in nutrients and we're going to talk about that soon
and how we can solve it there's also a lot of information coming out regarding
vitamin supplements not being able to transfer most of their valuable
nutrients into our bodies and much of it just ends up passing through and ends up
in our waste there are many reasons for this including the difference between
how our bodies processed specific vitamins such as fat soluble versus
water soluble our bodies have a more difficult time breaking down a vitamin
rich pill than it does a carrot or some broccoli and in order for our bodies to
absorb the nutrients it has to be bonded with another digestive enzyme first
without that enzyme the nutrients simply goes to waste
there are studies there would suggest eating food with
your vitamin supplements to aid in the body's ability to extract the nutrients
out of the pill and we still suggest eating your veggies as your primary
source of nutrient finally it's been shown that a high-stress job or
environment causes adrenaline to pump through the body which breaks down
vitamin C and destroys other nutrients which further adds to nutritional
deficiencies there's also cortisol the stress hormone
which is released into the body when under stress and causes chemical changes
and imbalances that an excess amounts can lead to depression mental illness
interference with learning and memory and even lowers immune function and bone
density not to mention increases weight gain
blood pressure cholesterol heart disease and so on therefore in addition to
keeping our body's levels of nutrients and balance maintaining a healthy
environment or at the very least a practice of deep calm breathing when we
get stressed can also help maintain a nutritional balance in our body and if
